channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Blast on Crimean Bridge Deals Blow to Russian War Effort in Ukraine
item.description: Any impediment to traffic on the bridge could affect Russia’s ability to wage war in southern Ukraine, where Ukraine’s forces have been fighting an increasingly effective counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Black smoke billowed from a fire on the Kerch Strait Bridge that links Crimea to Russia on Friday.

item.title: An American in Ukraine Finds the War He’s Been Searching For
item.description: For an unconventional former Marine colonel, Ukraine represents the morally just war that eluded him his entire career. But how much can he and his military start-up help?
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrew Milburn, founder of The Mozart Group, with Richie, a rescued mutt who has become the group’s mascot.

item.title: ‘Happy Birthday, Mr. President’: Ukrainians Celebrate Bridge Blast With Memes.
item.description: The bridge has both practical and symbolic resonance.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: A couple took a selfie in front of an artwork shaped as a big stamp named “Cotton to the Crimean Bridge.

item.title: How Insurers Exploited Medicare Advantage for Billions
item.description: By next year, half of Medicare beneficiaries will have a private Medicare Advantage plan. Most large insurers in the program have been accused in court of fraud.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

item.title: How Trump Deflected Repeated Demands to Return Documents
item.description: The former president exhibited a pattern of dissembling about the material he took from the White House, creating legal risk not just for himself but also some of his lawyers.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump spent a year and a half deflecting demands from the federal government to return documents.

item.title: J.D. Vance’s First Attempt to Renew Ohio Crumbled Quickly
item.description: In 2017, the Republican candidate for Senate started a nonprofit group to tackle the social ills he had written about in his “Hillbilly Elegy” memoir. It fell apart within two years.
item.dc:creator: David A. Fahrenthold
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: J.D. Vance at a campaign event in Columbus, Ohio, on Wednesday.

item.title: Egypt’s New Administrative Capital Rises, but at What Price?
item.description: It is the grandest in a slew of megaprojects spearheaded by the president. But as the country limps through a dire economic crisis, there are doubts about whether it can afford his grandiose dreams.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: The future business district in Egypt’s new capital, a megaproject just outside Cairo, in 2021.

item.title: NFL, Players Union Agree to Change Concussion Protocol
item.description: The league and the union said the concussion protocol was followed after Dolphins quarterback Tua Tagovailoa hit his head two weeks ago. But his return to that game has prompted a change in the protocol.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas and Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:description: Miami Dolphins quarterback Tua Tagovailoa, right, with Coach Mike McDaniel during the fourth quarter of a game against the Buffalo Bills on Sept. 25. Tagovailoa had hit his head earlier in the game but was allowed to return to action.

item.title: What Are Your ‘Non-Negotiables’? Readers Share Wellness Rituals
item.description: Reading Nancy Drew. Watching the birds every day. Counting yellow doors. Thousands of Times readers shared their wellness “non-negotiables.”
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Andrea Chronopoulos

item.title: Their Loved Ones Died. Preserved Tattoos Offer a Way to Keep Them Close.
item.description: Laws in most states allow mourners to remove and preserve tattoos as memorial works of art. An Ohio company, Save My Ink Forever, is the pioneer.
item.dc:creator: McKenna Oxenden
item.media:credit: Daniel Lozada for The New York Times

item.title: The Brave Women Protesters in Iran Deserve More U.S. Support
item.description: Diplomatic efforts toward a nuclear deal must go hand in hand with American support for Iran’s protest movement.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Donald Trump and Herschel Walker: The Unholy Alliance
item.description: Republicans sink to a new low in defending Walker.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd

item.title: From Moscow to Tehran, a Crisis of Illiberalism
item.description: The liberal West is in trouble, but its rivals still aren’t ready to supplant it.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A house used by Russian forces in the village of Kamyanka, Ukraine.

item.title: Nicolás Maduro Is President of Venezuela Whether the U.S. Likes It or Not
item.description: The White House needs a Venezuela policy based on fact, not fiction. And the fact is that Maduro is president of Venezuela and Guaidó is not.
item.dc:creator: William Neuman

item.title: A 50/50 Custody Arrangement Could Save Your Marriage
item.description: Married heterosexual motherhood in America is a game no one wins.
item.dc:creator: Amy Shearn

item.title: A Lost Manuscript Shows the Fire Barack Obama Couldn’t Reveal on the Campaign Trail
item.description: At Harvard Law, he wrote a blistering manifesto he never published. Its searing advice could help Democrats escape their current political quagmire.
item.dc:creator: Timothy Shenk

item.title: How a Still-Segregated Country Holds Us All Back
item.description: The legal scholar Aziz Rana examines the consequences of racial division.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie

item.title: What Nobel Prize-Winner Annie Ernaux Understands About the Past
item.description: Ernaux’s work insists that nothing in life is simple. And it is from that complexity that her work — and, indeed, her very voice — emerges.
item.dc:creator: Sheila Heti

item.title: ‘The Run-Up’: Can Democrats Catch up to Years of Republican Unity?
item.description: The overturning of Roe v. Wade has given Democrats a rallying issue to mobilize around before the midterms. Can they catch up to years of Republican unity?
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times

item.title: Hangover Anxiety: How a Night of Drinking Can Tank Your Mood
item.description: Consuming alcohol can mess with your emotions the next day by causing stress hormones to spike and sleep to be disrupted overnight.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: How to Learn My Love Language
item.description: A Deaf man has been let down by every lover he’s ever had. This time might be different.

item.title: Did the Pandemic Deepen Relationships in Your Life? We Want To Hear About It.
item.description: Tell us about relationships that started during the pandemic and ones that have evolved or been shaped by the last few years.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Naomieh Jovin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The pandemic has affected all kinds of relationships, from family bonds and friendships to romantic connections.

item.title: Children Killed in Thailand Massacre Are Laid to Rest
item.description: The town of Uthai Sawan in Thailand, a Buddhist-majority country, began formally mourning the victims of a mass killing at a day care center, most of them children.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Ryn Jirenuwat
item.media:credit: Andre Malerba for The New York Times

item.title: Wildfire Destroys a Piece of Black History in Rural California
item.description: The Lincoln Heights community endured for decades, despite segregation, economic hardship and a pandemic. Then came the Mill fire.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Brian L. Frank for The New York Times
item.media:description: When the Mill fire ripped through Weed, Calif., just before Labor Day weekend, the hardest-hit area was a historically Black neighborhood that dates back nearly a century.

item.title: Tropical Storm Julia Strengthens Into a Hurricane
item.description: The storm was headed toward Nicaragua, where it is expected to bring heavy rainfall that could trigger dangerous flash flooding and mudslides, forecasters said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: Rain falls in El Progreso, Honduras, before Hurricane Julia’s arrival Saturday.

item.title: More College Athletes Are Trekking to Ironman
item.description: The extreme triathlon has long been out of reach for many young athletes because of financial hurdles and timing demands. New rules and the coronavirus pandemic changed that.
item.dc:creator: David W. Chen
item.media:credit: Mia A'i for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some college athletes turned to bicycling, swimming and running during the coronavirus pandemic. The Ironman allowed them to show off their improved skills.

item.title: The Joy Workout
item.description: Six research-backed moves to improve your mood
item.dc:creator: Kelly McGonigal

item.title: Gut Healing Is TikTok’s Latest Trend. Does It Work?
item.description: Despite what social media might have you believe, there is no overnight shortcut to better digestive health.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: What is E.M.D.R.? Understanding the Trauma Therapy Practice
item.description: The once-experimental trauma treatment has become increasingly popular. Here’s how the therapy works.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Sophie Park
item.category: The Body Keeps the Score: Brain, Mind and Body in the Healing of Trauma (Book)
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Amsterdam’ Review: A Madcap Mystery With Many Whirring Parts
item.description: Christian Bale, Margot Robbie and John David Washington lead a crowded cast of zanies in David O. Russell’s latest screwball outing.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
